Description: Mule or donkey from a rhyton, with a shallow hole pierced in the mouth. A head broken from body. Hollow from two-piece mould; ears modelled and added: one is lost. Micaceous brown clay, with an orange-brown surface and grey core.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Temple of Aphrodite (Naukratis), Context Φ16 or 17
Curator's comments: Close parallel from Naukratis (Cambridge, Fitzwilliam Museum GR.16.1899 and EA 1911,0710.95 likely come from same mould series). The remaining objects in the Registration Sequence EA 1911,0710.92 to 106 apparently came from 26th-Dynasty contexts at Naukratis. They are both handmade and mould-made, and several of them are Cypriote. 'This appears stylistically to be later than the seventh- to sixth-century objects registered with it; a fifth- or fourth-century BC date seems more likely' (Bailey 2008, 186, Terracotta IV). Bailey suggests this is an Egyptian and figurine, with comparanda that all come from Naukratis (Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, no. 1896-1908.E4790, thought to be from Naukratis; Coulson et al. 1996, 143, fig. 54:11, suggesting Hellenistic date; Near: Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge, GR.16.1899). The clay is very fine and, though similar to Nile silt, more likely to be East Greek. This is not a terracotta figure, but a mould-made piece from a rhyton.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3762)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.421) (Phase 1)
